revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=May 2013}}{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Hornby plc | logo = [[Image:Hornby logo.svg|250px|Hornby Logo]] | type = [[Public company|Public]] ({{lse|HRN}}) | founder = [[Frank Hornby]] | key_people = | industry = Model railway components | products = | revenue = [[Pound sterling|£]]55.76 million (2016) | operating_income = -£13.12 million (2007) | net_income = -£13.71 million (2016) | num_employees = 200 (2010) | parent = | subsid = | footnotes = | owner = Phoenix Asset Management | foundation = {{Start date and age|1901}} (as Hornby Hobbies Ltd.)
{{Start date and age|1980}} (as Hornby Railways) | location = [[Margate]], [[Kent]], [[England]], [[United Kingdom|U.K.]] | homepage = [http://www.hornby.com www.hornby.com] }} '''Hornby Railways''' is a British [[model railway]] brand. Its roots date back to 1901, when founder [[Frank Hornby]] received a patent for his [[Meccano]] construction toy. The first clockwork train was produced in 1920. In 1938, Hornby launched its first [[00 gauge]] train. In 1964, Hornby and Meccano were bought by their competitor, [[Tri-Ang]],{{Cite book | author=Brown, Kenneth Douglas | authorlink= | coauthors= | title=The British Toy Business: A History since 1700 | date=| publisher=Hambledon & London | location= | isbn=1-85285-136-8 | pages=183–184}} and sold on when Tri-ang went into receivership. Hornby Railways became independent in the 1980s, and became listed on the [[London Stock Exchange]], but due to recent{{when|date=December 2017}} financial troubles is presently majority owned by turnaround specialist [[Phoenix Asset Management]]. ==History== ===Early history: 1920–1938 === [[File:Hornby early logo.png|thumb|right|A characteristic logotype]] [[File:JLL Childhood Collection- Model Trains- station 2753c.JPG|thumb|Hornby O gauge tinplate models]] Hornby was at first a tradename for the railway productions of [[Meccano Ltd]] and based in [[Liverpool]], which released its first train, a [[clockwork]] [[0 gauge]] (1:48) model, in 1920. An electric train soon followed but was under-designed and the few that were made were sold in France. In 1925, a much more successful electric model was introduced, operating on the high voltage of 110 volts [[Alternating current|AC]] power. Safety concerns saw low voltage 4V and then 6V motors introduced, followed by a reliable 20V AC system, which was developed in the early 1930s. However, clockwork remained the mainstay of the Hornby 0 gauge trains until 1937 and became the only power available in Liverpool-made 0 gauge trains from 1949. Competitors in the UK were [[Leeds Model Company]] and [[Bassett-Lowke]]. A factory was established in [[France]], which developed its own range of French outline trains, but Liverpool dominated export activity elsewhere, with large numbers of Hornby trains exported to [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], [[Argentina]] and Scandinavia. Even though the export models were often painted in 'foreign' liveries, Hornby trains looked very British. Hornby attempted to break into the American market by setting up a factory in 1927 in [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], to make American-style trains. These were colourful and attractive, but low-market and only clockwork. They probably would have failed in the marketplace because several established U.S. firms could undercut them and Hornby offered no better-class goods or electric models, but the Wall Street Crash precipitated matters. In late 1929, Meccano Ltd. sold its New Jersey factory to the [[A. C. Gilbert Company]] and Hornby trains had vanished from the U.S. market by 1930. The leftover inventory was sold in [[Canada]] and in the UK and some of the tooling was reused for products in other markets. ===Hornby Dublo era: 1938–1963=== [[File:Hornby Dublo logo.gif|thumb|right|Logo, 1956–1961]] [[File:City of Liverpool locomotive model.jpg|thumb|Hornby Dublo model of an [[LMS Coronation Class|LMS ''Coronation'']] locomotive ''City of Liverpool'' ]] Meccano introduced its [[OO scale]] trains in 1938 under the name 'Hornby Dublo'. The locomotives were diecast metal, and the carriages and wagons were generally made of tinplate. This was a very well planned range of electric and clockwork models, successfully consolidating 12 V DC as the standard for OO scale. This led to the adoption of OO as a broadly accepted modelling standard in the UK, whereas much of the rest of the world adopted HO scale. As for their O gauge locomotives, electric Hornby Dublo locomotives ran on a [[Third rail (model railroading)|third rail]] electric system with the track built on a pressed tinplate base. Both OO and HO use the same track gauge, but their scales are different. Beginning as literally "half O gauge", the HO models of continental prototypes at 3.5 mm/foot scale were workable but Hornby chose to slightly increase the scale to 4 mm/foot for the smaller British prototypes, to provide more internal space for a motor. This has had the effect, remaining to this day, of making their gauge an apparent 4 ft 1 ½ in rather than the true standard gauge of 4 ft 8 ½ in. The range expanded quickly, but was curtailed from 1940 due to [[World War II]], production being completely suspended in 1942. Production resumed after the war but did not reach full capacity until 1948. Clockwork models were not produced in 00 scale after the war. In 2008, a special commemorative model of [[LNER Class A4 4498 Sir Nigel Gresley]] was produced, in period packaging, to celebrate the 70th anniversary of this introduction. Like its counterparts [[Bassett-Lowke]] and [[Edward Exley Limited|Exley]] in the UK and [[Lionel, LLC|Lionel]] and [[American Flyer]] in the US, Hornby thrived in the first half of the 1950s but struggled in the second half of the decade. The company was slow to recognise the threat posed by rival manufacturers (particularly Triang-Rovex) and to realise the potential of plastic. In 1959, far too late, Hornby introduced two-rail track and moulded plastic rolling stock (the Super Detail series), but even then the system was complicated and difficult to use in comparison to its rivals. With the benefit of hindsight, the policy of keeping the faith with its existing three-rail users whilst bringing the two-rail system to the market was a mistake that cost the company dearly. Whilst all the newer plastic-wheeled rolling stock was compatible with either system, the locomotives (and track) most definitely were not, requiring the two parallel productions of practically every locomotive* in the range to be offered in both formats. Meanwhile, the company persisted in producing a range of very old-fashioned 0 gauge models, in 1957 completely retooling much of the range instead of taking the opportunity to discontinue it, indicative of major failings at management level. (* With the exception of the very first two-rail locomotive, a Southern Region R1 0-6-0 tank engine) ===Tri-ang Hornby: 1964–1972=== [[File:Triang-Hornby logo.jpg|thumb|right|Logo, 1966–1972]] In 1964, [[Lines Bros Ltd]]., the parent company of rival [[Tri-ang Railways]], purchased [[Meccano Ltd]]., and merged Hornby and Tri-ang into ''Tri-ang Hornby''. The former Hornby line was discontinued in favour of Tri-ang's less costly plastic designs. The Hornby Dublo tooling was sold to [[G & R Wrenn]], which continued to make most of the loco range and 'superdetail' rolling stock. Remaining stocks of 0 gauge were either scrapped or sold to the local retailer Hattons. ===Hornby Railways: 1972–1980=== [[File:Hornby Railways logo.jpg|thumb|right|Logo, 1978–1996]] [[File:Hornby 9F 2-10-0 Evening star.jpg|thumb|right|A Hornby model of a [[BR standard class 9F]]]] The Tri-ang group was disbanded in 1971 when Meccano Ltd's owner Lines Bros. filed for bankruptcy. The former Tri-ang Hornby was sold to Dunbee-Combex-Marx, becoming ''Hornby Railways'' in 1972. By 1976 Hornby was facing challenges from [[Palitoy]] and [[Airfix]], both of which were producing high quality detailed models. Detail on the models was upgraded to make the product line more attractive to adult hobbyists. === Zero 1 === A 16 channel command control system named ''Zero 1'' was introduced in late 1979. Zero 1 was based on digital, not analog, technology, and as such was a forerunner to the [[NMRA]] [[Digital Command Control]] (DCC) system, which appeared in the 1990s. Advertisements claimed that 16 locomotives could be operated independently at the same time. Though an important milestone, Zero 1 was not widely successful; the controller units and decoder modules required for the locomotives were expensive, but with clean track and well serviced locos the system worked well. Control of points and other accessories was available in a very simple manner. Locomotives equipped with a Zero 1 decoder could not be used on conventional direct current systems, making it difficult to run one's locomotives on friends' layouts or club layouts. This was a common issue with command control systems in that time period. Locomotives with no decoder could not be used on a Zero 1 layout either. The Master Control unit was discontinued in 1985, the Slave controller, Loco Modules, and accessory modules were still available until the late 1980s. The system is still used today by many modellers, highlighted by the demand on such sites like eBay for the items in the second hand market. Despite being on the market for a short time, Zero 1 had the largest installed base among command control systems in the early 1980s in North America, according to a reader survey done by ''Model Railroader'' magazine. Zero 1 had 3 'phased' introductions. :Phase 1 = Master controller and basic system (Master controller, Slave, hand held slave unit and Loco modules) :Phase 2 = Accessory control (Points, Signals etc.) :Phase 3 = Micro Mimic display (Allowed for LED'S to represent status of points and signals on a mimic display panel) The system was mains dependent, so a 50 Hz Version and 60 Hz version were available (60 Hz US only) Main Master unit discontinued in 1986, and finally the last time Loco Modules were listed was in the 1991 catalogue 'Limited supplies of R955 Loco module are available'. Repairs to Zero 1 units were no longer undertaken by Hornby due to them stating 'Lack of available parts required'. === Rocket === As part of the 1980 [[Rocket 150]] celebrations, Hornby released a [[live steam]]-powered 3½" gauge locomotive, a model of the ''[[Stephenson's Rocket]]''{{cite web|url=http://uk.geocities.com/rolywilliams/hornby_rocket.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027110036/http://uk.geocities.com/rolywilliams/hornby_rocket.html|archive-date=2009-10-27|title=Hornby G100 Stephenson's Rocket|dead-url=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://www.familie-bennett.de/rocket/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091231052131/http://www.familie-bennett.de/rocket/|archive-date=2009-12-31|title=Stephen(son)'s Rocket Homepage}} A major goal was to make real live steam accessible to an indoor domestic environment. The boiler was considerably smaller than the external diameter, surrounded by a thick insulating jacket to prevent burns. It was fuelled by butane gas, from cigarette lighter refills. To provide more torque from the small cylinders, gearing was adeptly hidden between the cranks and the wheels. The track was of asymmetric moulded plastic units, representing the [[fishbelly rail]]s of the period. These could be assembled either way round, to give either curved or straight track. By 1980, the market was extremely tough and Dunbee-Combex-Marx was liquidated, placing Hornby in [[receivership]]. ===Hornby Hobbies Limited: 1980–2015=== [[Image:Hornby HST 43087-02.jpg|thumb|right|In 2006 a [[Cotswold Rail]] [[British Rail Class 43 (HST)|Class 43]] HST power car carried a livery advertising Hornby. It has since been repainted.]] In 1980, Hornby became ''Hornby Hobbies'' and in 1981 a management buyout saw the company back on a sound footing. It went public in 1986.{{Citation needed|date=June 2018}} By the early 1990s Hornby again faced competition from newcomers such as [[Dapol]] and established foreign manufacturers, including [[Lima (models)|Lima]] and [[Bachmann Industries]]. Manufacturing was moved to [[Guangdong]] province in China in 1995, completed by 1999, in a cost-cutting exercise.[http://www.cbbc.org/the_review/review_archive/company_profiles/21.html One The Right Track] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206101026/http://www.cbbc.org/the_review/review_archive/company_profiles/21.html |date=2008-12-06 }}, China-Britain Business Council, 2005 As part of the process Hornby also bought in some of Dapol's products and also some of the old Airfix moulds (by then owned by Dapol). Train sets based on [[Hornby Thomas And Friends|Thomas the Tank Engine and Friends]] and [[Harry Potter]] {{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/2966288.stm|title=Potter keeps Hornby profits on track|publisher=BBC News|date=2005-06-05|accessdate=2008-05-02}} (the "[[Hogwarts Express]]") have been particularly profitable ventures. In September 2003 Hornby released its first [[steam engine|steam-powered]] 00 gauge locomotive, a model of the record-breaking [[Mallard (locomotive)|''Mallard'']]. Several other "[[Live Steam]]" locomotives have now been produced. [[File:Hornby 00 scale model of a Stirling GNR Class J13 (LNER Class J52).jpg|thumb|[[GNR Class J13]] model of this period]] Since then Hornby has bought [[Lima (models)|Lima]], an Italian model railway equipment manufacturer that had previously acquired [[Jouef]], a French manufacturer. Some of the ex-Lima models appear in the main Hornby products list. This range is known as [[Hornby International]]. This acquisition also included the [[Rivarossi]] line of HO-scale products, also originally from Italy, and the Arnold brand of N-scale products. They also took over the Spanish model railway company Electrotren. Electrotren had been the Spanish importer for [[Scalextric]], sold in Spain as Superslot. The takeover was at the request of the Spanish company and was not due to obvious financial problems. They have remained independent outside of the Hornby International umbrella. With competition mainly from [[Bachmann Industries]], and to a much lesser extent from minor and generally niche players such as the Danish model railway company [[Heljan]], [[Dapol]], [[Vi Trains]] and [[Peco]], Hornby Railways now (in 2008) produce a large range of highly detailed British steam and diesel locomotives, such as the [[BR Standard Class 9F|BR 9F]], [[LNER Class A4]], [[SR Merchant Navy Class|SR Merchant Navy]], [[British Rail Class 60|Class 60]], [[British Rail Class 50|Class 50]], [[British Rail Class 31|Class 31]] and [[British Rail Class 08|Class 08]]. In November 2006, Hornby Hobbies acquired [[Airfix]] and [[Humbrol]] paints for the sum of £2.6 million.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/6134988.stm|title=Hornby snaps up Airfix for £2.6m|publisher=BBC News|date=2006-11-10|accessdate=2008-05-02}} The parent company, [[Humbrol]], had gone into administration earlier that year after cashflow problems. Airfix fans had been concerned that it could be the end of the brand, but just as the name Hornby was once a tradename of Meccano, Airfix is now a successful tradename of Hornby. In May 2008, Hornby announced the acquisition of [[Corgi Classics Limited]], one of the world's oldest makers of collectable die-cast models of trucks, buses, cars and aeroplanes, from [[Corgi International Limited]] for £7.5million.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/mergersNews/idUKL0166601520080501|title=Hornby to buy Corgi|publisher=Reuters|date=2008-05-01|accessdate=2008-05-01|first=Mark|last=Potter}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7376855.stm|title=Hornby to buy Corgi in £7.5m deal|publisher=BBC News|date=2008-05-01|accessdate=2008-05-01}} In 2009, the Hornby Shop and Visitor Centre was in development. Christmas 2009 saw the launch of the new Hornby Shop at [[Margate]] in [[Kent]], with the visitor centre still in production. July 2010 saw the opening of the Hornby Shop And Visitor Centre.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=November 2014}} ===Financial troubles, PAM takeover=== From 2015, Hornby plc began to announce a series of declining financial results. The major reason behind the decline Hornby declared was two fold, with the decline in the number of (now aged, and hence older) collecting customers, and a lack of interest in modelling as a hobby in light of the digitization and advancement of the internet games industry. After the PLC shares dropped by more than 50% in a year, at the 2016 results Hornby declared that it planned to cut more than half of the toys it made, after discovering that it generated 90% of its profits from only 50% of its range.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-39702623|title=Hornby backs chairman in shareholder row|date=2017-04-25|accessdate=2017-11-23|website=Bbc.co.uk}} In the year to 31 March 2017, revenues fell further to £47.4m from £55.8m, while underlying losses widened to £6.3m from a £5.7m deficit in 2016. The financial declines culminated in July 2017, when the largest shareholder Phoenix Asset Management (PAM) agreed to buy 17.6 million Hornby shares for 32.375p from the second largest - and activist/protagonist shareholder - New Pistoia Income (NPI), which gave PAM a 55.2% holding in the company. This triggered under stock exchange rules a mandatory takeover offer of Hornby by PAM, at the NPI strike price of 32.375p, valuing Hornby at £27.4million.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-40371393|title=Hornby says takeover bid undervalues firm|date=2017-06-22|accessdate=2017-11-23|website=Bbc.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/business/news/phoenix-asset-management-to-launch-mandatory-takeover-offer-for-troubled-hornby-35850169.html|title=Phoenix Asset Management to launch mandatory takeover offer for troubled Hornby|website=Belfasttelegraph.co.uk|accessdate=2017-11-23}} As a result of the takeover, the chairman of Hornby resigned from the company in August 2017, followed by the Chief Executive in September 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-41223672|title=Toymaker Hornby's boss to step down|date=2017-09-11|accessdate=2017-11-23|website=Bbc.co.uk}} In October 2017 PAM announced their new management team who would join the company and steer through the turnaround. {{Cite news|url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kent-business/county-news/hobby-model-expert-lyndon-davies-new-chief-executive-hornby-sandwich-kent-133072/|title='Hobby expert' to lead Hornby|work=Kent Online|access-date=2018-07-02|language=en-GB}} They were Lyndon Davies, former Mettoy employee and owner of Oxford Diecast.{{Cite web|url=http://www.gaugemaster.com/articles/product-spotlight/oxford-diecast-Interview.html|title=BIG INTERVIEW - Lyndon Davies of Oxford|website=www.gaugemaster.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-02}} Simon Kohler, ex Hornby marketing manager {{Cite web|url=https://www.lner.info/forums/viewtopic.php?t=9927|title=Simon Kohler leaves Hornby - The LNER Encyclopedia|website=www.lner.info|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-07-02}} and Tim Mulhall, also from Oxford Diecast and credited with knowledge of the International market, having been the former importer for Hornby International brands in the UK {{Cite web|url=https://www.herefordtimes.com/news/4168978.Herefordshire_Company_is_a_real_model_of_success/|title=Herefordshire Company is a real model of success|website=Hereford Times|language=en|access-date=2018-07-02}}. The end of year Annual Report for March 2018 revealed how serious the position was for the company, showing further slumps in revenue (down to £35.7m) and a widening pre-tax loss (up to £7.6m).{{Cite web|url=http://www.stockmarketwire.com/article/6017787/Hornby-losses-widen-as-revenue-slumps.html|title=Hornby losses widen as revenue slumps {{!}} 19 June 2018 {{!}} Stock Market Wire|website=www.stockmarketwire.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-02}} ==Gauges== While Lionel thrived in the O Gauge market, American Flyer in the S gauge, and Bachmann in the HO gauge, Hornby thrived in the OO gauge since Lionels' OO gauge demand dropped in the 1940s and 1950s. ==Collector and enthusiasts' groups== Pre-1964 Hornby trains have enjoyed a level of adult collector interest since the 1940s. In 1969 the '''Hornby Railway Collector's Association''' was founded to cater for this and currently enjoys a membership approaching 3000, producing 10 journals a year, as well as other literature. Publications on older Hornby and Meccano products are dominated by those published by New Cavendish Books as "The Hornby Companion Series", in particular Chris & Julie Graebe's "The Hornby Gauge 0 System" and Michael Foster's sister volume on Hornby Dublo. Triang-Hornby and later Hornby products are catered for by the '''[[Train Collectors Association|Train Collectors' Association]]'''. ==Brands== ===Lima=== {{main|Lima (models)}} Lima was an Italian company that was a popular, affordable supplier of model railway material but market pressures in the mid-1990s led to Lima merging with [[Rivarossi]], [[Arnold (models)|Arnold]], and [[Jouef]]. When these consolidations failed and operations ceased in 2004, Hornby Railways acquired Lima's assets. As of mid 2006, a range of these products has been made available under the Hornby International brand, refitted with NEM couplings and sprung buffers and sockets for [[Digital Command Control|DCC]] decoders. Lima also had a popular OO gauge range much like Hornby, which strengthened the case for acquisition. ===Jouef=== {{main|Jouef}} ===Arnold=== {{main|Arnold_(models)}} ===Rivarossi=== {{main|Rivarossi}} ===Skaledale=== ‘Skaledale’ is a range of resin buildings and track accessories produced for 00 gauge railways by Hornby Hobbies Ltd. Production began in 2003 when an initial range of only 6 items were distributed into the market place. The interest and demand proved so positive that the range increased the following year to include new domestic style buildings plus the introduction of station and trackside buildings. Many of the models are similar to those of 'Lyddle End' (a range which followed 'Skaledale'), but these “N” Gauge buildings are produced to a smaller scale of 1:148. The Skaledale range comprises station buildings, platforms, trackside accessories, shops, houses, churches, monuments and street furniture. Forbes Outfitters and St. Andrews Church for example, provided the inspiration for their scaled down models, although others are adapted to suit a particular price point or subject. The station and trackside buildings are inspired by actual structures but again in some cases adapted to suit manufacturing constraints. Some of the station pieces were inspired by [[Goathland railway station]]. ===Lyddle End=== '''Lyddle End''' is the range of [[N scale]] [[Rail transport modelling|model railway]] buildings for Hornby Railways. The buildings are created from high quality die cast [[resin]] and are made to represent the fictional village of Lyddle End, somewhere in England. Most of the buildings are models of [[Great Western Railway|GWR]] style buildings made out of red sandstone. Hornby created these buildings thanks to the success of their 00 gauge buildings{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}}, which they call ''Skaledale''. Many of the buildings are the same as their Skaledale equivalent, except in different scales, to save the cost of designing a new model. They are generally released about 6 months to a year behind their OO counterparts. When Hornby announced their 2010 range, Lyddle End was not mentioned, presumably ended. ==In media== An attempt to build the world's longest model railway formed the final episode of ''[[James May's Toy Stories]]''. May, who had previously identified the train set as his "absolute favourite",{{YouTube|zZ8IjZ3tUas|James May's Top Toys}} hoped that a train would run successfully along the length of the [[Tarka Trail]], which is a disused {{convert|37|mi|km|adj=on}} long railway line in [[North Devon]].{{cite web|url=http://tarka-country.co.uk/tarkaproject/recinfra.html |title=Recreational Infrastructure: Tarka Trail |accessdate=2009-07-31 |publisher=Tarka Country |work=Tarka Project |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080515170916/http://www.tarka-country.co.uk/tarkaproject/recinfra.html |archivedate=2008-05-15 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/6088019/Vandals-disrupt-Top-Gear-presenter-James-Mays-model-train-record-bid.html |title=Vandals disrupt Top Gear presenter James May's model train record bid |work=The Telegraph |location=London |date=25 Aug 2009}} Hornby was heavily involved, providing the track and the prototype of their OO gauge [[British Rail Class 395|British Rail Class 395 ''Javelin'']] train. Simon Kohler, marketing manager of Hornby model railways, said that the train which travels at just {{convert|1|mph|km/h}} failed two miles short of Bideford station; but he also told BBC News "Even though the last locomotive gave up the ghost at Instow, we did link the track. In April 2011 James tried again, this time against the Germans. All the trains reached their destinations and the British team won.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} ==See also== * [[Smokey Joe (model locomotive)|Smokey Joe]] * [[Hornby Virtual Railway]] * [[Hornby Track Master]] ==Notes== {{Reflist}} == References == * Foster, Michael (1980) ''Hornby Dublo Trains: 1938–1964: The story of the perfect table railway'', Hornby Companion Series, vol. 3, New Cavendish Books, {{ISBN|0-904568-18-0}} * {{cite book |title=Tri-ang Hornby |series=The Story of Rovex |volume=2 1965–1971 |first=Pat |last=Hammond |publisher=New Cavendish Books |year=1998 |location=London |isbn=1-872727-58-1 }} * {{cite book |title=Hornby Railways |series=The Story of Rovex |volume=3 1972–1996 |first=Pat |last=Hammond |publisher=New Cavendish Books |year=2005 |location=London |isbn=1-904562-00-0 }} * Hornby PLC (2004) ''Hornby OO Scale Model Railways: Fiftieth Edition'', Product catalogue: R8108, Limited anniversary edition, [[European Article Number|EAN]] 501-0-9634810-8-7 * Schneider, Lewis (May 2000) Hornby's made-in-USA trains, ''Classic Toy Trains'', vol. 13, p. 84 * Kohler, Simon (April 2011) - {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox person | name = Hossein Rajabian | image = Hossein Rajabian Iranian Filmmaker & Photographer.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1984|7|5}} | nationality = [[Iran]] | education = [[Drama|Dramatic literature]] '''(Unfinished)''' | occupation = Filmmaker, Writer, Photographer | awards = [[Rebellion artist in the world in 2017|Rebellion's Artist in the World 2017]] }}
'''Hossein Rajabian''' ({{lang-fa|[[:fa:حسین رجبیان|حسین رجبیان]]}}; born 5 July 1984) is an Iranian Filmmaker, Writer and Photographer who was imprisoned in 2015 on charges related to his filmmaking.
== Artistic activities == Hossein Rajabian started off his artistic career in a theater school. Later he made his debut in cinema by making and editing short and documentary films.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.clermont-filmfest.com/index.php?m=157&c=3&id_film=100076571&o=|title=International Short Film Festival – Clermont-Ferrand|website=www.clermont-filmfest.com|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC-ZAsGnbjUTzgdV6xhsyNgg|title=Hossein Rajabian Iranian Filmmaker & Photographer|website=YouTube|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref> His artistic résumé is dotted with different projects ranging from making (feature) films,<ref>{{Citation|last=Hossein Rajabian Iranian Filmmaker & Photographer|title=Trailer The Upside down Triangle A Film By Hossein Rajabian آنونس مثلث واژگون فیلم حسین رجبیان|date=26 December 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f7ByMNMbaRc|accessdate=2016-04-05}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Hossein Rajabian Iranian Filmmaker & Photographer|title=The Upside-down Triangle A Film By Hossein Rajabian نسخه کامل مثلث واژگون فیلمی از حسین رجبیان|date=23 April 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bI7YNkcZLrI|accessdate=2016-04-24}}</ref> writing a number of screenplays for feature films, essays on cinema, plays, and carrying out artistic-photographical projects and film workshops.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/hosseinrajabian/|title=hossein rajabian|last=|first=|date=|website=instagram@hosseinrajabian|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref> He also found his way into the Faculty of Art and Architecture in Tehran and studied [[Drama|dramatic literature]], but he never finished his studies there. Later he gained admission to the [[University of Music and Performing Arts, Vienna|University of Music and Performing Arts]], Vienna to continue his studies in cinema and theater, but he was captured by security forces and his passport was seized before setting out for [[Austria]] and was barred from taking up academic studies at home and abroad.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.iranwire.com/features/6959/|title=Artists Sentenced to Prison|website=en.iranwire.com|access-date=2016-04-17}}</ref> "[[People in distance]]" is the name of a black and white photography project implemented by Hossein Rajabian.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://zhmag.net/2017/11/people-in-distance/|title=Hossein Rajabian - ZH Magazine|date=2017-11-06|work=ZH Magazine|access-date=2017-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Filmography===
==== Short ==== *''So So'' (fiction, 2003, 6 minutes) *''[[Navigation (Film)|Navigation]]'' (documentary, 2005, 43 minutes) <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oWMouq8s2Z4|title="Navigation" is the name of a documentary film directed by Hossein Rajabian|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> *''[[To Revolution Square]]'' (documentary, 2006, 22 minutes) <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z6YyTOOr0mQ|title=To Revolution Square is the name of a documentary short film in 2006 directed by Hossein Rajabian|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> *''Some Redundant Word in The Dictionary'' (fiction, 2010, 20 minutes) <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BrcgR2-Fw94|title=some redundant word in the dictionary|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> *''Lines'' (documentary, 2010 to present) <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nKn8DFOjG70|title=Lines A film by hossein rajabian|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
==== Film Workshop ==== *''Film Workshop The Experimental & Creatively attitude''<ref>{{Citation|last=Artist Freedom|title=Hossein Rajabian Film Workshop . حسین رجبیان فیلم ورکشاپ|date=2017-09-02|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L2gb_ffzeUA&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-09-02}}</ref>
==== Photography project ==== *''[[People in distance]] is the name of a [[black and white photography]] project implemented by Hossein Rajabian''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hosseinrajabian.webs.com/photography|title=hossein rajabian|website=hossein rajabian|access-date=2017-06-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/cogalleryhosseinrajabian/|title=+Co Gallery|website=Flickr|language=en-us|access-date=2017-06-18}}</ref>
==== Feature film scripts ==== *''The stone falls in water (2009)'' *''[[The Upside-down Triangle]] (2011)''
==== Feature ==== *''[[The Upside-down Triangle]] (fiction, 2015, 106 minutes) <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f7ByMNMbaRc|title=Trailer The Upside down Triangle A Film By Hossein Rajabian|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Apprehension and court case == After finishing his first feature film, Rajabian was arrested by Iranian security forces on 5 October 2013 outside his office in [[Sari, Iran|Sari]] alongside two musicians, and was transferred to Ward 2-A of [[Evin Prison]] where all three of them were held in solitary confinement for more than two months and were threatened with televised confessions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://hra-news.org/en/3-artists-sentenced-imprisonment-fine-appeal-court-tehran#more-15094|title=3 Artists Sentenced to Imprisonment and Fine by the Appeal Court of Tehran|website=Hrana – News Agancy|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/24/filmmaker-two-musicians-three-years-prison-iran|title=Film-maker and two musicians face three years prison in Iran|last=Dehghan|first=Saeed Kamali|date=24 March 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-04-06}}</ref> He was released on bail (around $66,000) in mid-December, pending trial.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iranhumanrights.org/2016/01/call-on-iranian-authorities-to-drop-charges-on-two-musicians-and-a-filmmaker/|title=Call on Iranian authorities to drop charges on two musicians and a filmmaker|website=International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran|language=en-us|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref> Two years later, his case was heard at Branch 28 of Tehran [[Islamic Revolutionary Court|Revolutionary Court]] which was presided over by Judge Moghisseh (Summer 2015). He was sentenced to six years in prison and fines for pursuing illegal cinematic activities, launching propaganda against the establishment and hurling insults at sanctities. On appeal, his sentence was changed to three years imprisonment and three years of suspended jail and fines.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artsfreedom.org/?p=10967|title=Iran: Two musicians and a filmmaker sentenced|website=Artsfreedom|language=en-US|access-date=2016-04-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.iranwire.com/features/6959/|title=Artists Sentenced to Prison|website=en.iranwire.com|access-date=2016-04-03}}</ref>
== Imprisonment and hunger strike == Hossein Rajabian was sent to the ward 7 of [[Evin Prison]] in [[Tehran]]. After spending one third of his total period of imprisonment (that is 11 months), he went on [[hunger strike]] to protest against unjust trial, lack of medical facilities, and transfer of his brother to another ward called section 8 of the same prison. During the first hunger strike period, which lasted 14 days, he was transferred to hospital because of pulmonary infection and he could not continue his hunger strike because of the interference of the representative of the prosecutor who was sent as an intermediary. After some time, he sent an open letter to the judicial authorities of Iran and went again on strike which brought him the supports of international artists.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://voiceproject.org/post_news/help-us-defend-freedom-of-expression/|title=Help us step up our efforts to defend freedom of expression. Join Peter Gabriel, Johnny Depp, Pussy Riot’s Nadya Tolokonnikova, Edward Sharpe’s Alex Ebert, Tom Morello, Ana Tijoux. - Voice Project|newspaper=Voice Project|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/cinema/2016/11/19/03002-20161119ARTFIG00026-johnny-depp-peter-gabriel-une-pause-contre-la-censure.php|title=Johnny Depp, Peter Gabriel : une pause contre la censure|last=Trigalot|first=Yoko|date=2016-11-19|newspaper=Le Figaro|language=fr-FR|issn=0182-5852|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref> After 36 days of hunger strike, he could convince the judicial authorities of Iran to review his case and grant him medical leave for the treatment of his left kidney suffered from infections and blood arising out of hunger strike.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.journalismisnotacrime.com/en/news/1567/|title=Punishment for Brothers on Hunger Strike|website=www.journalismisnotacrime.com|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.amnesty.or.jp/en/get-involved/ua/ua/2016ua041.html|title=JAILED MUSICIAN AND FILMMAKER ON HUNGER STRIKE: AMNESTY JAPAN|newspaper=AMNESTY JAPAN|language=en-us|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://voiceproject.org/post_news/two-iranian-musicians-on-hunger-strike/|title=Imprisoned Iranian Musicians on Hunger Strike - Voice Project|newspaper=Voice Project|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://freemuse.org/archives/13035|title=Iran: Artists call for support in letter from prison|date=2016-11-01|newspaper=Freemuse|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite Abuse {{!}} PEN America|website=pen.org|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde13/5106/2016/en/|title=Document|website=www.amnesty.org|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite Iran|language=en-us|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iranhumanrights.org/2016/11/mehdi-hossein-rajabian-2/|title=Ailing Music Distributor Refuses Hospital Treatment, Vows to Hunger Strike Until Demands Met|newspaper=International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran|language=en-us|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iranhumanrights.org/2016/10/mehdi-rajabian-and-hossein-rajabian/|title=Tricked Into Ending Hunger Strike, Imprisoned Music Distributors Resume Quest for Justice|newspaper=International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran|language=en-us|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref> he, after a contentious struggle with the judicial officer of the prison was sent to the ward 8 for punishment.
== Official reactions of the senior officials of the world == After imprisonment of Hossein Rajabian, senior officials of the world started to react officially to this sentence. For instance, [[Ban Ki-moon]], secretary general of the [[United Nations]], issued a special declaration about the human rights in the world. In the ninth page of the annual declaration, he refers to the conditions of Hossein Rajabian in the Iranian prisons, and asks the Iranian authorities to release this filmmaker unconditionally.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://freemuse.org/archives/12297|title=UN: "Artistic expression is not a crime" – Special Rapporteurs urge the Iranian government to free jailed artists|date=2016-06-24|newspaper=Freemuse|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=53993#.WEz4ZyHl_uo|title=UN News - UN rights office ‘appalled’ by Iran’s sentencing of anti-death penalty campaigner|last=Section|first=United Nations News Service|date=2016-05-20|website=UN News Service Section|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://freemuse.org/archives/12297|title=UN: "Artistic expression is not a crime" – Special Rapporteurs urge the Iranian government to free jailed artists|date=2016-06-24|newspaper=Freemuse|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=54318#.WEz38SHl_uo|title=UN News - Detention, heavy fines for artistic expression in Iran ‘unacceptable,’ say UN rights experts|last=Section|first=United Nations News Service|date=2016-06-24|website=UN News Service Section|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref> [[United Nations|UN]] Special Rapporteur for [[human rights in Iran]] [[Asma Jahangir]], in her annual report called for the unconditional release of Hossein Rajabian and other prisoners in Iran.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/265708.pdf|title=According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of America|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://irannewsupdate.com/news/human-rights/3624-human-rights-advocates-call-attention-to-worsening-crackdown-in-iran.html|title=Human Rights Advocates Call Attention to Worsening Crackdown in Iran|last=editor-m|work=Iran news update|access-date=2017-03-28|language=en-gb}}</ref> It can be referred to the protesting speech delivered by [[Wilfred Moore]], the Canadian Liberal Senator in the senate against the Iranian authorities and in support of Hossein Rajabian.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bcrgroup.us/canadian-liberal-senator-defends-rights-of-artists-in-dange.html|title=Canadian Liberal Senator Defends Rights of Artists in Danger of Imprisonment in Iran|website=bcrgroup.us|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://liberalsenateforum.ca/hansard/human-rights-abuses-iran-inquiry-4/|title=Human Rights Abuses in Iran—Inquiry - Liberal Senate Forum|date=2016-05-12|work=Liberal Senate Forum|access-date=2017-08-27|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sencanada.ca/en/Content/Sen/chamber/421/debates/036db_2016-05-12-e#44|title=Senate of Canada - Debates|last=Canada|first=Senate of|website=Senate of Canada|language=en-CA|access-date=2017-08-27}}</ref> After the imprisonment of Hossein Rajabian, [[Åse Kleveland]] who is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] an artist and political leader declared her support to him, and asked for unconditional release of him and all artists imprisoned throughout the world.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rb.no/kultur/nyheter/ase-kleveland/jeg-har-hatt-gleden-av-a-se-ayatollahene-i-hvitoyet/s/5-43-300850|title=– Jeg har hatt gleden av å se ayatollahene i hvitøyet|date=2016-05-31|work=www.rb.no|access-date=2017-03-28|language=no}}</ref> Following that, [[Philip Luther]], the head of [[Amnesty International]] published an official video talking about Hossein Rajabian and asked all artists of the world to launch a worldwide campaign to support him.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/cinema/2016/11/19/03002-20161119ARTFIG00026-johnny-depp-peter-gabriel-une-pause-contre-la-censure.php|title=Johnny Depp, Peter Gabriel : une pause contre la censure|last=Trigalot|first=Yoko|date=2016-11-19|newspaper=Le Figaro|language=fr-FR|issn=0182-5852|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Iranian Filmmaker & Photographer in رجبیان|date=2016-12-07|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=69-M04CV20M|accessdate=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2016/11/iran-musicians-and-activists-launch-campaign-to-free-jailed-artists/|title=Iran: Musicians and activists launch campaign to free jailed artists|website=www.amnesty.org|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref> After organizing an international petition by the Amnesty International, [[Johnny Depp]], the American actor, and [[Peter Gabriel]], the well-known musician initiated a campaign with the motto "[[Art is not a Crime]]" to protest against censorship and support Rajabian and all other imprisoned artists.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/cinema/2016/11/19/03002-20161119ARTFIG00026-johnny-depp-peter-gabriel-une-pause-contre-la-censure.php|title=Johnny Depp, Peter Gabriel : une pause contre la censure|last=Trigalot|first=Yoko|date=2016-11-19|work=Le Figaro|access-date=2017-03-28|language=fr-FR|issn=0182-5852}}</ref>
A petition was signed by more than 12,000 people of different human right activists and artists addressing the Iranian authorities to review the judicial case of Rajabian and several other prisoners.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fidh.org/IMG/pdf/20160122_iran_rouhani_visit_ol_en_final.pdf|title=Letter to the Iranian authorities for freedom Hossein Rajabian|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cafebabel.co.uk/article/prisons-and-human-rights-in-iran.html|title=Prisons and human rights in Iran|website=Cafebabel|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://hyperallergic.com/335205/two-imprisoned-iranian-artists-pen-letter-of-protest/|title=Two Imprisoned Iranian Artists Pen Letter of Protest|date=2016-11-02|newspaper=Hyperallergic|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref> Finally, the [[United Nations Human Rights Committee]] unanimously passed a resolution against Iranian government for the flagrant violation of [[human rights]] as a reaction to the collective hunger strike of Hossein Rajabian and seven other political and ideological prisoners of [[Evin Prison]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://themediaexpress.com/2016/11/16/the-u-n-adopted-a-resolution-that-condemns-human-rights-violations-in-iran/|title=The U.N. adopted a resolution that condemns human rights violations in Iran|last=Davison|first=Craig|date=2016-11-16|website=The Media Express|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite Canada|first=Global Affairs Canada|website=GAC|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref> Following that, the [[United States Senate]] extended the sanctions imposed on Iran for the violation of human rights for another ten years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2016/12/senate-iran-sanctions-vote-232061|title=Senate votes unanimously to extend Iran sanctions|newspaper=POLITICO|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/12/01/politics/senate-extends-iran-sanctions/index.html|title=Senate votes to extend sanctions against Iran|last=CNN|first=Ted Barrett|website=CNN|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.international.gc.ca/media/aff/news-communiques/2015/12/18a.aspx?lang=eng|title=Canada and international community call on Iran to improve its human rights record|last=Government of Canada|first=Global Affairs Canada|website=GAC|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.iranhumanrights.org/2016/11/un-resolution-november15/|title=85 UN Member States Say Iran Must Improve Its Human Rights|newspaper=International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran|language=en-us|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/press/en/2016/gashc4188.doc.htm|title=Third Committee Approves 5 Draft Resolutions on Situations in Syria, Iran, Crimea, Introduces 5 Others Concerning Self-Determination, Enhanced Cooperation {{!}} Meetings Coverage and Press Releases|website=www.un.org|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref> The citizens of European countries initiated a supporting campaign and a sit-in in front of the Iranian Embassies in different countries while showing his photos.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/12/02/a-jailed-iranian-musician-texts-from-his-hospital-bed-dont-forget-me/|title=A jailed Iranian musician texts from his hospital bed: Don’t forget me|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-12-11}}</ref> The annual report [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]] on Human Rights in Iran in 2016, to the situation of prisoner filmmaker Hossein Rajabian.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2016/nea/265496.htm|title=The annual report U.S. Department of State on Human Rights in Iran|last=|first=|date=|work=U.S. Department of State|access-date=2017-08-27|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Film release in protest == In protest at his sentence and seizure of his film materials, Hossein Rajabian released the medium-quality copy of his film ''[[The Upside-down Triangle]]'' online.<ref>{{Citation|last=Hossein Rajabian Iranian Filmmaker & Photographer|title=The Upside-down Triangle A Film By Hossein Rajabian نسخه کامل مثلث واژگون فیلمی از حسین رجبیان|date=23 April 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bI7YNkcZLrI|accessdate=2016-04-24}}</ref>
== Media reaction to court sentence ==
The news on the imprisonment of Hossein Rajabian, the Iranian artist, had globally great worldwide reflection, and it was covered by many news agencies including [[The Washington Post|Washington Post]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/12/02/a-jailed-iranian-musician-texts-from-his-hospital-bed-dont-forget-me/|title=A jailed Iranian musician texts from his hospital bed: Don’t forget me|website=Washington Post|access-date=2017-03-28}}</ref> [[The Guardian|Guardian]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/iran-blog/2016/dec/01/iranian-musician-hospitalised-after-one-month-hunger-strike|title=Iranian musician hospitalised after one-month hunger strike|last=correspondent|first=Saeed Kamali Dehghan Iran|date=2016-12-01|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-03-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/mar/24/filmmaker-two-musicians-three-years-prison-iran|title=Film-maker and two musicians face three years prison in Iran|last=Dehghan|first=Saeed Kamali|date=2016-03-24|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-03-28|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>[[The Independent|Independent]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/iran-human-rights-abuses-evin-prison-donald-trump-push-federica-mogherini-united-nations-speak-up-a7954006.html|title=This is what Trump should do about Iran at his first UN General Assembly meeting|date=2017-09-18|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-10-01|language=en-GB}}</ref> [[Al Arabiya|Al-Arabiya]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Iranian Filmmaker & Photographer in Jail|title=Hossein Rajabian Filmmaker & Mehdi Rajabian Music...خبر عربی حسین رجبیان فیلمساز و مهدی رجبیان موسیق|date=2016-03-06|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ciTStQMF10w|accessdate=2017-03-28}}</ref> [[BBC News|BBC]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/persian/iran/2016/02/160225_nm_amnesty_artists|title=عفو بین‌الملل به حکم زندان سه هنرمند ایرانی اعتراض کرد|website=BBC Persian|access-date=2017-03-28}}</ref> [[Le Figaro]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/cinema/2016/11/19/03002-20161119ARTFIG00026-johnny-depp-peter-gabriel-une-pause-contre-la-censure.php|title=Johnny Depp, Peter Gabriel : une pause contre la censure|last=Trigalot|first=Yoko|date=2016-11-19|work=Le Figaro|access-date=2017-03-28|language=fr-FR|issn=0182-5852}}</ref> [[CNN]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://arabic.cnn.com/world/2016/03/03/amnesty-campaign-against-iran-crackdown-freedom-expression|title=CNN Arabic - العفو الدولية تهاجم "قمع إيران للفن" وتشن حملة على "استهزاء طهران السافر بحقوق حرية التعبير" بعد تعذيب وإدانة فنانين إيرانيين|work=CNN Arabic|access-date=2017-03-28|language=ar-AR}}</ref> [[Al Jazeera|AL JAZEERA]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/news/humanrights/2016/3/3/%D8%A3%D9%85%D9%86%D8%B3%D8%AA%D9%8A-%D8%AA%D8%B9%D8%B0%D9%8A%D8%A8-%D9%88%D9%82%D9%85%D8%B9-%D9%84%D9%81%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A%D9%86-%D8%A5%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A%D9%8A%D9%86|title=أمنستي: تعذيب وقمع لفنانين إيرانيين|access-date=2017-03-28}}</ref> etc. The arrest and conviction of Hossein Rajabian was given extensive coverage by media outlets in Iran and other countries.In an exclusive interview, Amnesty International's Deputy Director for the Middle East and North Africa Said Boumedouha expressed objection to Rajabian's sentence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/iran-blog/2016/mar/04/iranian-election-seven-key-human-rights-challenges-facing-president-rouhani|title=Iran: seven key human rights challenges facing President Rouhani|last=Dehghan|first=Saeed Kamali|date=4 March 2016|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-04-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/press-releases/2016/03/iran-tortured-filmmaker-and-musicians-face-imminent-arrest-amid-crackdown-on-artists/|title=Iran: Tortured filmmaker and musicians face imminent arrest amid crackdown on artists|website=www.amnesty.org|access-date=2016-04-05}}</ref> Afterwards, [[Amnesty International]] launched a global campaign and petition calling on all artists across the world to sign the petition and join the campaign. More than 20,000 artists from four corners of the world joined the campaign,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://winterswijkseweekkrant.nl/nieuws/schrijfactie-iran-6-jaar-cel-voor-filmmaker-en-muzikanten-1.5920219|title=Schrijfactie Iran: 6 jaar cel voor filmmaker en Artist,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BVkvCm1AvSD/?taken-by=shirin__neshat|title=Instagram post by Shirin Neshat • Jun 20, 2017 at 7:59pm Earlier, other institutions such as [[PEN International]], [[International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran|International Campaign for Human Rights]] [in Iran],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pen-international.org/01/2016/call-on-iranian-authorities-to-drop-charges-on-two-musicians-and-a-filmmaker/|title=Iran: Drop Charges Against Filmmaker and Musicians PEN {{multiple issues| {{cleanup rewrite|date=September 2016}} {{unref|date=August 2018}} {{notable|date=August 2018}} }} {{ Infobox organization |name = بنیاد میراث ایران
The Iranian Heritage Foundation |image = [[File:Iran Heritage Foundation Logo.png|200px|Iran Heritage Foundation Logo]] |size = |abbreviation = |motto= |formation = 1990 |type = [[Foundation (nonprofit)|Foundation]], [[Nonprofit Organization]] |headquarters = 63 New Cavendish Street [[London]] W1G 7LP [[United Kingdom]] |location = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] |leader_title2 = Chairmen |leader_name2 = Ali Rashidian and Alireza Rastegar |leader_title3 = CEO |leader_name3 = John Curtis |budget = |website ={{URL|http://www.iranheritage.org|}} }} The Iran Heritage Foundation (IHF) is a non-political UK registered charity with a mission to promote and preserve the history, languages and cultures of Iran and the Persianate world, covering all periods of Iranian civilization from ancient to modern. == History and organisation == The Iran Heritage Foundation was founded in the UK in 1990 and registered as a charity in 1991 (no. 1001785). It is funded by contributions from individuals and corporations, and through various fundraising events. The Foundation does not accept financial support from any government organisations or lobbying groups. IHF is governed by a body of trustees supported by an advisory board and grant-giving committees. === Chairpersons and Directors === * Chair ** Vahid Alaghband (1990-2017) * co-Chairs ** Ali Rashidian (2017-) ** Alireza Rastegar (2017-) * Directors / CEOs ** Farhad Hakimzadeh (1995-2007) ** Farad Azima (2008-2013) ** John Curtis (2014-) === IHF America === In 2010 IHF established an independent parallel organisation in the USA known as IHF America. This organisation supported a curatorial post at the Freer Sackler gallery in Washington DC and played a major role in the British Museum’s tour of the Cyrus Cylinder exhibition to five different US venues in 2013. == Object / Remit == The remit of IHF is wide and includes archaeology, history, art history, literature, the performing arts, film, photography, music and contemporary art. IHF achieves its objectives by organising and supporting exhibitions, cultural events and conferences, giving grants, sponsoring publications, and supporting posts in universities and museums. Cultural/educational institutions that have been supported by IHF include the universities of Cambridge, Edinburgh, Exeter, London, Oxford, Reading, and St Andrews, and the British Library, the British Museum, the Courtauld Institute of Art, Tate Modern, and the Victoria & Albert Museum. == Activities == The Foundation organises a regular series of events including lectures, panel discussions, performances, and film screenings. Major international conferences organised by IHF include: ‘Iran's Natural Heritage’ (2014); ‘From Persepolis to Isfahan: Safeguarding Cultural Heritage’ (2015); and two conferences on Tappeh Sialk and ancient Kashan (2017, 2018). IHF also awards annual grants for academic and scholarly research as well as for contemporary and performing arts projects and festivals. These grants are awarded by two separate committees made up of external advisors. IHF supports and sponsors events and activities which promote Iranian culture and history, including exhibitions such as ‘Forgotten Empire’ and ‘Shah Abbas’ at the British Museum in 2005 and 2009. Additionally, the 2013 exhibition ‘The Cyrus Cylinder and Ancient Persia’, which toured around the US, was organised by the British Museum in partnership with the Iran Heritage Foundation and the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery. An ongoing major project supported by the IHF is the Golha Archive, an online digitized and fully indexed archive of the Golha radio programmes broadcast on Iranian National Radio from 1956 until 1979. == See also == [[Iranian studies]] == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.iranheritage.org Iran Heritage Foundation] [[Category:Arts foundations]] [[Category:Iranian culture]] [[Category:Charities based in London]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{refimprove|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox artist | bgcolour = #6495ED | name = Gulgee <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: | image = Gulgee.jpg --> | imagesize = | caption = | birth_name = Ismail Gulgee (The Gulgeez) | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1926|10|25}} | birth_place = [[Peshawar, Pakistan]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2007|12|16|1926|10|25}} | death_place = [[Karachi, Pakistan]] | nationality = [[Pakistan]] | field = [[Calligraphy]], Painting, Sculptures | training = Self-taught | movement = [[Islamic calligraphy]] | works = | patrons = | influenced by = | influenced = | awards = [[Pride of Performance]], [[Sitara-e-Imtiaz]] (twice), [[Hilal-e-Imtiaz]] }}
'''Ismail Gulgee – The Gulgeez''' (25 October 1926 – 16 December 2007)<ref name="Gulgee">{{cite web|url=http://kp.gov.pk/page/gulgee/page_type/person|publisher=kp.gov.pk|title=Gulgee}}</ref><ref name="CBC">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/artdesign/story/2007/12/19/Pakistan-artist.html |title=Gulgee and his wife appeared to have been dead at least three days, police said |work=[[CBC News]] |date=December 19, 2007 |accessdate=August 25, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602105920/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/artdesign/story/2007/12/19/pakistan-artist.html |archivedate= 2 June 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ''[[Pride of Performance]], [[Sitara-e-Imtiaz]] (twice), [[Hilal-e-Imtiaz]],'' was a Pakistani artist born in [[Peshawar]].<ref name="Gulgee"/> He was a qualified engineer in the US and self-taught [[Abstract art|abstract painter]] and [[portrait painter]]. Before 1959, as portraitist, he painted the entire [[Barakzai dynasty|Afghan Royal Family]]. From about 1960 on, he was noted as an abstract painter influenced by the tradition of [[Islamic calligraphy]] and by the American "[[action painting]]" idiom.
==Biography==
Gulgee was born on 26 October 1926 at Karimpura locality in [[Peshawar]], Pakistan. Initially, he went to [[Lawrence College Murree]] and then to [[Aligarh University]] to study civil engineering before heading off to the US for continuing his higher education. Gulgee started to paint while acquiring his training as an engineer in the United States at [[Columbia University]] and then [[Harvard]]. His first exhibition was in 1950.
Gulgee was a gifted and consummately skilled naturalistic [[portrait]] painter who had enjoyed (according to Partha Mitter) "lavish state support" and plenty of elite commissions in this capacity. Nevertheless, he was perhaps best known worldwide for his [[abstract art|abstract]] work, which was inspired by [[Islamic calligraphy]] and was also influenced by the "[[action painting]]" movement of the 1950s and 1960s (Mitter notes that [[Elaine Hamilton-O'Neal|Elaine Hamilton]] was a strong influence in this direction). This is perhaps a natural enough stylistic combination since in both Islamic calligraphy and action painting a high value is placed on the unity and energy of gestural flow. As with the works of other action painters or [[abstract expressionist]]s, Gulgee's canvases were often quite large. He was also known for using materials such as mirror glass and gold or silver leaf in his oil paintings, so that they were in fact [[mixed media]] pieces.
According to the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] (see external links): "Gulgee's calligraphy paintings are abstract and gestural interpretations of [[Arabic]] and [[Urdu]] letters. His sweeping layers of paint explore the formal qualities of oil paint while they make references to [[Islamic]] design elements." [http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/wepk/hd_wepk.htm]
Beginning in the 1960s (if not earlier), Gulgee also created sculptures, including bronze pieces that were (like so many of his paintings) calligraphic in form and inspiration, and sometimes specifically based on verses from the [[Quran]] [source:artnet.com].
His paintings were bright and full of color, but the paint was put on with great sensitivity, and paintings vibrate with intense feeling. Areas sing with luminous, thin color; thick blobs of paint pulsate with fiberglass tears, the brush swirls strong and free. The total effect used to be very free, yet considered and well thought out. They work enormously well, because it was all orchestrated with great care and concentration.
His son [[Amin Gulgee]] is also a famous artist.<ref name="CBC"/>
[Note: the name is also spelled "Guljee", "Gulji", or "Gulgi" in some sources.]
==International and special assignments==
Guljee, as he was famously known, received many requests for his paintings internationally, from the [[Saudi royal family]] to the [[Islamabad presidency]]. Many of his works are placed in the [[Faisal Mosque]] in [[Islamabad]].<ref name="CBC"/> Guljee received many awards, including from Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Japan and France.
==Exhibition and personal life==
Gulgee's exhibitions have mostly been available to few people. Keeping that in mind and high demand from public and lovers of his works, an art gallery for Gulgee has been built in [[Clifton, Karachi]] near [[South City Hospital]] and [[Sea View Karachi]]. Gulgee mostly painted for his own inspirations and vision. Although selected paintings are available for sale in Gulgee art gallery. Gulgee was last based in Boat Basin in Karachi. He has a son [[Amin Gulgee]].
==Murder==
Gulgee, his wife Zarrin Gulgee and a maid were found dead by strangulation<ref name="CBC"/> in their house on the evening of 19 December 2007 by his servants. Police suspect that all three had been murdered.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/7151914.stm] While the bodies were found on the 19th, officials report that they had apparently been deceased for three days, leading to a speculative death date of 16 December 2007. Their bodies were found bound and gagged in separate rooms of the house. The initial cause of death for all three has been attributed to suffocation. According to press reports, his son reported that Gulgee's car and driver are missing. Gulgee was buried on the evening of 20 December 2007 in Karachi.
==See also==
*[[Islamic calligraphy]] (primary source of inspiration for Gulgee's abstract works) *[[Action painting]] ([[Gestural abstraction]]) *[[Elaine Hamilton-O'Neal|Elaine Hamilton]] (American action painter and colleague who influenced Gulgee, according to Partha Mitter) *[[Mixed media]] *[[Abstract expressionism]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox philosopher | name = James Phillips | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | era = [[Contemporary philosophy]] | region = [[Western philosophy]] | school_tradition = [[Continental philosophy|Continental]] | main_interests = [[Aesthetics]]
[[Political Philosophy]]
[[Cinema Studies]] | notable_ideas = | influences = | influenced = }} '''James Andrew Phillips''' is an associate professor of [[philosophy]] at the [[University of New South Wales]]. He is known for his research on [[philosophy of art]] and [[Martin Heidegger]]'s thought.[http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/colloquy/download/colloquy_issue_11_may_2006/padgett.pdf A review of "Heidegger`s Volk: Between National Socialism and Poetry"] by [[Andrew Padgett]][http://www.klinikum.uni-heidelberg.de/fileadmin/zpm/psychatrie/ppp2004/manuskript/phillips.pdf Time and Memory in Freud and Heidegger: An Unlikely Congruence] by James Phillips[http://the.sagepub.com/content/87/1/112.extract My Own Private Swabia. On the Idiocy of Heidegger's Nationalism] by [[Robert Ian Savage]][http://www.h-net.org/reviews/showpdf.php?id=11565 Heidegger and National Socialism: New Contributions to an Old Debate] by [[Robin Celikates]][https://ndpr.nd.edu/news/23293-the-equivocation-of-reason-kleist-reading-kant/ A review of "The Equivocation of Reason: Kleist Reading Kant"] by [[Robert E. Norton]][https://ndpr.nd.edu/news/24871-heidegger-s-volk-between-national-socialism-and-poetry/ A review of "Heidegger's Volk: Between National Socialism and Poetry"] by [[Hans Sluga]] ==Life== After receiving his MA in [[Comparative Literature]] and [[Critical Theory]] from [[Monash University]], he studied as a Ph.D. student in philosophy in both Austria and Germany and finished his doctorate under [[Jeff Malpas]] at the [[University of Tasmania]]. Phillips has been a visiting fellow at the Institute of Advanced Studies in the Humanities ([[University of Edinburgh]]) and [[National Humanities Center]] in North Carolina. ==Bibliography== * Phillips JA, 2019, ''Sternberg and Dietrich: The Phenomenology of Spectacle'', [[Oxford University Press]] * Phillips JA, (ed.), 2008, ''Cinematic Thinking'', [[Stanford University Press]], Stanford * Phillips JA, 2007, ''The Equivocation of Reason: Kleist reading Kant'', Stanford University Press * Phillips JA, 2005, ''Heidegger`s Volk: Between National Socialism and Poetry'', Stanford University Press * Phillips JA, 2009, 'Beckett's Boredom', in ''Essays on Boredom and Modernity'', edn. 1, Rodopi, Amsterdam ==See also== *[[Martin Heidegger and Nazism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://hal.arts.unsw.edu.au/about-us/people/james-phillips/ James Phillips at UNSW] {{Martin Heidegger}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Phillips, James Andrew}} [[Category:21st-century philosophers]] [[Category:University of New South Wales faculty]] [[Category:Continental philosophers]] [[Category:Australian academics]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Political philosophers]] [[Category:Phenomenologists]] [[Category:Heidegger scholars]] [[Category:Philosophers of art]] [[Category:University of Tasmania alumni]] [[Category:Monash University alumni]] [[Category:Australian philosophers]] [[Category:Film theorists]] [[Category:Critical theorists]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Pumpkin oil - CIELab.png|right|thumb|300px|Presentation of the changing color of pumpkin oil (in the CIELab color space) as its thickness or concentration changes]] '''Kreft's dichromaticity index''' (DI) is a [[measurement|measure]] for quantification of [[dichromatism]]. It is defined as the difference in [[hue]] angle (Δh<sub>ab</sub>) between the [[color]] of the sample at the dilution, where the [[colorfulness|chroma]] (color saturation) is maximal, and the color of four times more diluted (or thinner) and four times more concentrated (or thicker) sample. The two hue angle differences are called the dichromaticity index towards lighter (Kreft's DI<sub>L</sub>) and dichromaticity index towards darker (Kreft's DI<sub>D</sub>) respectively.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Kreft S, Kreft M. | title= Quantification of dichromatism: a characteristic of color in transparent materials |url=http://www.opticsinfobase.org/josaa/abstract.cfm?URI=josaa-26-7-1576 | journal=Journal of the Optical Society of America A | volume=26 | pages=1576–1581 | year=2009 | doi = 10.1364/JOSAA.26.001576 |bibcode = 2009JOSAA..26.1576K | issue=7 | pmid=19568292}}</ref> Kreft's dichromaticity indexes DI<sub>L</sub> and DI<sub>D</sub> for [[pumpkin seed oil]], which is one of the most dichromatic substances, are −9 and −44, respectively. This means, that pumpkin seed oil changes its color from green-yellow to orange-red (for 44 [[Degree (angle)|degrees]] in [[Lab color space]]) when the thickness of the observed layer is increased from cca 0.5 mm to 2 mm; and it changes slightly towards green (for 9 degrees) if its thickness is reduced for four-fold.
The color of pumpkin oil at increasing thickness or concentration presented in [[CIELAB]] colorspace diagram. Straight lines are vectors showing hue (angle) and chroma (length) of the color at maximal chroma (toward the square mark), and the colors of four-fold less or more diluted or thick pumpkin oil (DI<sub>L</sub> and DI<sub>D</sub>). Note that DI<sub>D</sub> is −44.1 degrees and DI<sub>L</sub> corresponds to −8.97 degrees.
Dichromaticity (DI<sub>L</sub> and DI<sub>D</sub>) of selected substances, calculated from their VIS absorption spectra by the computer algorithm “Dichromaticity index calculator”: {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" ! Substance !! DI<sub>L</sub> !! DI<sub>D</sub> !! Maximal chroma !! Angle at maximal chroma |- | [[1,1-diethyl-2,2-cyanine iodide]]||4.3||-1.1||107.1||44.6 |- | [[acridine orange]]||-10.1||-17.9||118.4||88.3 |- | [[acridine yellow]]||-2.1||-1.7||123.1||98.6 |- | [[auramine O]] ||-3.4||0.4||130.1||94.7 |- | [[beta carotene]]||-5.7||-7.0||131.8||91.5 |- | [[bilirubin]]||-4.7||-6.0||136.5||90.3 |- | [[bromophenol blue]] at pH 3.0||-12.4||-31.1||107.6||86.6 |- | [[bromophenol blue]] at pH 3.2||-14.6||-42.4||92.9||86.5 |- | [[bromophenol blue]] at pH 3.4||-48.9||-14.1||74.5||37.8 |- | [[bromophenol blue]] at pH 3.6||-51.4||-16.4||70.6||37.4 |- | [[bromophenol blue]] at pH 3.8||-49.8||-18.3||65.5||34.3 |- | [[bromophenol blue]] at pH 4.0||-26.5||-10.8||68.9||31.4 |- | [[bromophenol blue]] in water||-13.0||-34.7||104.7||86.4 |- | [[C3 indocyanine]]||8.2||17.3||89.3||348.0 |- | [[chlorophyll a]] in ether||29.2||60.7||50.4||201.4 |- | [[chlorophyll b]]||11.2||27.3||44.5||143.2 |- | [[coumarin 6]]||-2.0||-0.3||131.2||96.5 |- | [[coumarin 343]]||-1.9||0.0||120.9||99.6 |- | [[cryptocyanine]]||37.9||1.9||84.3||301.3 |- | [[crystal violet]] in glycerol||9.7||3.3||141.3||318.3 |- | [[crystal violet]] in water||9.3||3.7||142.0||319.1 |- | [[fluorescein|fluorescein dibase]]||-1.6||-6.9||120.4||75.4 |- | [[hemoglobin]] - oxy||-1.2||-5.6||108.4||42.6 |- | hemoglobin||-2.3||-5.9||62.3||19.0 |- | [[malachite green]]||7.3||24.4||61.2||223.2 |- | [[nile blue]] in methanol||34.9||7.8||78.3||288.9 |- | [[nile red]]||18.5||-9.5||103.2||45.9 |- | [[proflavin]] at pH 7||-6.1||-10.6||101.6||98.5 |- | [[pumpkin seed oil]]||-9.0||-44.1||59.8||102.2 |- | [[resazurin]]||33.2||40.6||36.2||331.3 |- | [[rhodamine]] 6G||21.9||-0.8||110.5||54.4 |- | [[vitamin B12|vitamin B<sub>12</sub>]]||34.8||-6.2||102.0||39.8 |- | |}
Maximal chroma: chroma at concentration (thickness) where the color of the substance has maximal chroma (saturation). Angle at maximal chroma: the hue, which is represented by the angle of the vector to the color with maximal chroma in the CIELAB colorspace diagram.

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Squib]] (link changed to [[Bristol-Myers Squibb]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
'''Lenthéric, Inc.''' is a manufacturer of perfumes, cosmetics, toilet preparations,<ref name="gossip">“Purely Gossip”, ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', 7 January 1942, pg. 15.</ref> hair spray, and shampoo.<ref name="acquires">“Helene Curtis Acquisition”, ''Wall Street Journal'', 12 October 1956, pg. 6.</ref>
== Corporate history == [[File:Salon national de la Mode Lenthéric.png|thumb| A lithographic poster promoting ''soins de beauté Lenthéric'' (Paris, before 1900).]] The name of the company was taken from Guillaume Lenthéric, a [[French people|French]] distiller and dispenser of perfumes in late 19th century [[France]]. He operated a small salon in 245 [[rue Saint-Honoré]] in [[Paris, France]], beginning in 1875.<ref>“Display Ad 94 — No Title”, ''Wall Street Journal'', 7 December 1954, pg. 17.</ref> The firm incorporated in 1924. Lenthéric became a [[subsidiary]] of [[Bristol-Myers Squibb|Squibb]], and was 90% controlled by the parent company in January 1942.<ref name="gossip" />
In 1947 Lenthéric, Inc., experienced a decline in earnings due to higher wages, advertising expenses, and vast returns of merchandise from retail stores, which trimmed inventories.<ref>“Abreast of the Market”, ''Wall Street Journal'', 11 October 1947, pg. 7.</ref> In 1951 the company hoped to increase sales by introducing a new line of makeup called ''Sheer Beauty''. It sold for less than $5. The firm also reduced the price of ''Debo'' deodorant from $1.35 to $1.00. This was accomplished by making the product in a plastic squeeze bottle rather than a glass bottle with [[atomizer nozzle|atomizer]].<ref>“Perfume and Powder Purveyors, Introduce Novelties”, ''Wall Street Journal'', 24 August 1951, pg. 1.</ref>
Squibb had manufacturing plants in [[Brooklyn, New York]] and [[New Brunswick, New Jersey]] in July 1952. It controlled the Squibb Building at [[Fifth Avenue]] and 58th Street in [[New York City]]. Squibb was acquired by the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation in the late summer of 1952.<ref>“Business Milestones”, ''Wall Street Journal'', 11 July 1952, pg. 6.</ref> [[Helene Curtis Industries, Inc.]], of [[Chicago, Illinois]] acquired the Lentheric, Inc., division of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation in October 1956.<ref name="acquires" />
In 1990, Old Bond Street, 88.5% owned by [[Wasserstein Perella & Co.]], purchased Lenthéric and [[Yardley of London|Yardley]] from [[SmithKline Beecham]].<ref>“Investor Group acquires SmithKline-Yardley,Lentheric from GlaxoSmithKline PLC through a leveraged buyout”, ''Thomson Financial Mergers & Acquisitions'', 7 July 1990.</ref> In 1998, Old Bond Street collapsed and Lenthéric was sold to Shaneel Enterprises Ltd.
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.lentheric.com/ Corporate website]
